channel.title: English Editorial Combined Feed
channel.description: Aggregated English editorial feed without duplicates

item.title: Climate change is not gender-blind, our response must not be either
item.description: Unicef notes that prolonged school closures increase the likelihood that girls will drop out permanently or be married off as families search for ways to cope.

item.title: Opinion / The interim government’s troubling continuity
item.description: The interim government seems more focused on areas where it should not be undertaking any initiatives.

item.title: UN Rohingya conference: Bangladesh must prioritise its security and stability
item.description: Bangladesh is carrying the weight of a genocide it did not commit, while the perpetrators in Myanmar remain untouched.

item.title: Understanding the dynamics of unemployment in Bangladesh
Dengue: Stuck in pilots while the outbreak worsens
Justice is first step towards peace in the CHT
Repeat of West’s Oslo ‘peace’ fraud
Letting corporations define diversity
Stepping up mosquito surveillance
Dowry laws under fire
Showpiece signals reflect Dhaka’s habit of superficial fixes
Khagrachhari violence demands answers and justice
item.description: Govt must run impartial investigation, end the cycle of violence in the hills

item.title: Take urgent steps to ensure safe level crossings
The Changing Face of Foreign Direct Investment
item.description: Once dominated by a handful of advanced economies, foreign direct investment is being reoriented toward Africa and Southeast Asia. At the heart of this shift is China, whose massive push into green manufacturing could accelerate the clean-energy transition and consolidate its industrial dominance.

item.title: Money Will Not Be Revolutionized
item.description: The future of money and payment systems will be characterized by evolution, not some radical crypto revolution of the kind envisioned by Bitcoin advocates. Money is too much a public good and national-security concern to be left to private, anonymous, decentralized actors.

item.title: Changing the narrative of climate loss and damage ahead of COP30
India’s Economy Is Stronger Than Trump Thinks
item.description: While US President Donald Trump’s tariff hikes and H-1B visa shake-up will likely deal a sharp blow to India’s export and IT sectors, they are far from fatal. In fact, with its vast population and robust domestic demand, India is better positioned than most to withstand external shocks.

item.title: Why we should think twice before adopting PR system
item.description: Every vote tells a story of hopes, frustrations, and dreams that shape a nation’s future.

item.title: INTERNATIONAL DAY FOR UNIVERSAL ACCESS TO INFORMATION / A year of silence from the Information Commission
item.description: Restoring the Information Commission is not optional; it is a constitutional duty.

item.title: Dengue's economic toll in Bangladesh
item.description: In July 2025, twelve-year-old Joya from Barguna fell ill with what first seemed like a simple fever, but within days she was diagnosed with dengue and rushed to a private clinic in Barishal as public hospitals were overflowing. Her eight-day stay in the clinic, including time in intensive care, cos

item.description: Provisions must be made to equip the NHRC with adequate financial and human resources to fulfil its mandate effectively.

item.description: Govt must make sure preventive services are not disrupted

item.title: The declining clout of American empire
item.description: "Those who do not remember the past are condemned to repeat it", said George Santayana, a great American philosopher. Gone are the days of Alexander the Great, Julius Caesar, Genghis Khan, Napoleon the Great and the likes. Preserving and protecting an empire today has become more complex and diffic

item.title: Gen Z is shaping the world in a way never seen before
item.description: The world's demography was never categorised by alphabetic letters like it has been done since the Millennials. Yet its next generation known in short Gen Z has captured the headlines more than their preceding and succeeding generations. The Millennials have no chance of getting more prominence tha

item.title: Rain, Roads, and Rubbish: Why Dhaka turns into a swimming pool every monsoon
Bangladesh stood with Palestine long before the West found its conscience
Tourism in Bangladesh: Picturesque natural marvels beckon
item.description: World Tourism Day is celebrated every year on September 27. This day is celebrated around the world to raise awareness about the social, cultural, political and economic importance of tourism. It has been celebrated in all member countries since 1980 under the direct supervision of the World Touris

item.title: Khatunganj Trade Hub
item.description: In the narrow, chaotic lanes of Khatunganj with the air thick with the scent of spices and the din of commerce, transactions worth over $250 million are sealed every day with little more than a handshake. In the heart of Chattogram lies Khatunganj -- not merely a wholesale marketplace but a living,

item.title: Cover Story newsletter: How we chose the cover image
item.description: The thinking behind our designs about free speech in America, spotting a genius and Britain going bust

item.title: The War Room newsletter: The best tanks of all time
item.description: In a bonus edition of our defence newsletter, Richard Cockett examines an icon from the battlefield

item.title: United States, Inc.
item.description: From “transactional” trade deals and “efficiency” drives to pay-to-play immigration policies, Donald Trump appears determined to govern the United States like a business. But a profit-seeking government will never provide an adequate supply of public goods, and the lawless version pursued by Trump, a serial bankrupt, is poorly suited to anything other than self-enrichment.

item.title: The Big Picture
Are US Democrats Really Soft on Crime?
item.description: While US President Donald Trump deploys National Guard troops to major cities governed by Democrats, the data show that violent crime rates are actually much higher elsewhere. If his show of cracking down on crime were based on the evidence, he would be focusing on the rural counties where many of his voters live.

item.title: Trump’s Peacemaker Hype
item.description: Donald Trump’s Nobel Peace Prize campaign – which he recently took to the United Nations General Assembly – has followed a familiar pattern: invent or inflate a problem, claim to have solved it, and then demand a reward. The Norwegian Nobel Committee will not be fooled, but the same cannot be said for Trump’s base.

item.title: Takaichi Sanae, the hardline nationalist who may soon lead Japan
item.description: She would be the country’s first woman prime minister—and pull its politics sharply to the right

item.title: Building a Global Order that Works for Africa
item.description: Africa’s underdevelopment can be largely attributed to its integration into the world economy through the slave trade, colonialism, and now debt-fueled neoliberalism. The continent’s leaders must dare to imagine a new multilateral system that values people over profit, care over competition, and collective dignity over extractive growth.

item.title: Are MAGA Voters Rational?
item.description: Since the study of economics relies on the assumption that people largely act in their rational self-interest, when people vote otherwise, economists are likely to blame faulty or missing information. But explaining the behavior of Donald Trump's supporters requires looking beyond economic rationality.

item.title: Tax at source, growth off track: Why reform cannot wait
“America First” Accounting Standards?
item.description: Donald Trump’s new SEC chairman has threatened to require foreign companies listed in the US to reconcile their international-standards-based reporting with US reporting principles. If he follows through, many firms may simply delist, striking a blow against globally integrated financial markets.

item.title: Answering Trump’s United Nations Challenge
item.description: The odds of reforming the multilateral system – which currently serves a few narrow interests – remain slim amid rising geopolitical tensions and growing populist sentiment in rich countries. To make progress on the Sustainable Development Goals, a more diverse group of actors must devise ways to circumvent systemic barriers.

item.title: The promise and pitfalls of Bangladesh’s PPP journey
Getting to Greener Steel
item.description: Coalbed methane is an underappreciated problem of global steel production. While cutting methane emissions in the steel supply chain will not produce green steel overnight, it could reduce the sector’s emissions by the equivalent of a billion tons of carbon annually, and at little cost.

item.title: With America Out, the Rest of the West Must Rise
item.description: The populist forces that propelled Donald Trump’s rise will continue to shape US politics long after he leaves office. Rather than wait around hoping for the US to re-embrace reason, democratic values, and global leadership, the “rest of the West” must step up to preserve the foundations of global stability and prosperity.

item.title: China Plans, America Reacts
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s transactional strain of industrial policy has prompted many to ask whether he has embraced Chinese-style state capitalism. But Trumponomics, lacking an overarching strategy and largely based on the whims of one man, is nothing like China’s comprehensive “all-of-government” approach.

item.title: The case for an overhaul: Diagnosis from the new PPP authority CEO
Robert Redford and the Leadership America Has Lost
item.description: Through his films, conservation efforts, and the Sundance festival, Robert Redford enjoyed global fame for most of his adult life. But unlike other world-famous figures nowadays, what ultimately defined him was not his status as a household name, but how he chose to use it.

item.description: In January 2024, a 6-year-old girl trapped inside a bullet-riddled car in Gaza City begged for someone to rescue her. Contact was lost with the first ambulance.
